December 20, 1900.

THE PROCESSION OF THE BOER'S
HEAD AT OXFORD.
BY AN OXFORD POST-GRADUATE.

WASHINGTON Irving describes in'his stories
of old Christmas at Bracebridge Hall how
the custom of bringing in the boar's head was
observed by the household of the Squire, that
delightful conservator of old English manners
and ceremonies. "I like the old custom," said
the Squire "not merely because it is stately and
pleasing in itself, but because it was observed at
the college at Oxford at which I was educated.
When Ihear the old song chanted, it brings to
mind the time when I wasyoung and gamesorne,—and the noble old college-hall,—and my
fellow-students loitering about in their black
gowns; many ofwhom, poor lads, are now in
their graves!"
And Irving observes, in a foot-note, that the
old custom is still kept up at the hall of Queen's
College, Oxford.
What Irving wrote fifty years ago still holds
good. On a recent Christmas Day I was present
in the hall of Queen's College, and witnessed the
quaint ceremony, heard the old chant that
Squire Bracebridge had heard in his young days
and never forgotten, and saw the students loitering around in black gowns in the noble old
college hall.
The hall is a fine lofty room, one of Sir Christopher Wren's designs, and is adorned with
many antique oil-paintings of kings,queens, and
benefactors. John Wycliffe, the early English
reformer, was a member of this college and a
great host of eminent men have been on its rolls,
—princes, poets, antiquarians and divines,—
among the princes, Edward the Black Prince,
and Henry V.
Two distinctive customs belong to Queen's
College and it clings to them almost religiously,
for these differentiate it from the twenty or more
other colleges at Oxford. One is this procession
of the boar's head at Christmas time. The
other is the gift of the needle and thread on

No. 5.

New Year's Day. At this latter ceremony, the
bursar presents each member or guest with a
needle and thread, repeating the words: "Take
this and be thrifty!" So has it been said every
year for many centuries.
The custom of the ushering-in of the boar's
head with the singing of a carol is said to commemorate the deliverance from death of a student of the college, who, while walking in the
country near Oxford studying his Aristotle, was
attacked by a wild boar from Shotover Forest.
He had no weapons. But Aristotle is a good
weapon when one knows how to use it. So he
thrust his Aristotle down the throat of the savage brute, and thus vaquished him. The next
day was Christmas, and they ate the boar on
that day, and ever since the same custom has
been observed.
This is how the custom is annually observed.
At half-past six the trumpet sounds forth some
hearty blasts. This is the signal that the procession is about to start from the kitchen and
the invited guests in the dining hall (and I
among them,)—wait in eager expectation for the
first appearance. First the provost of the college appeared, Dr. Magrath, who made a brief
speech in Latin. The provost is a learned man
and is not only provost of Queen's but vicechancellor of the University. He wore his official
gown. He was a handsome,dignified gentleman
with gray hair and beard.
After the speech the great oaken doors were
flung wide open, and the sounds of the carol began to be heard. A few minutes later the great
platter with the boar's head appeared. It was
carried on the shoulders of several college servitors. The boar's head was bravely and regally
arrayed. It lay on a bed of ivy and holly. It
was crowned with a great imitation golden
crown studded with imitation rubies. A cluster
of tiny college flags floated from each ear. And
under its saucy snout, between the two great
white tusks was a golden lemon.
As the procession reached the hall, it halted
and a collegian sang the first verse of the quaint

2

THE. NEWS-LETTER.

carol solo. Then the chorus was taken up by
the choir of men and boys—all gowned,—and the
procession moved again until the chorus ended,
then halted again while another verse was sung,
and so on to the end.
When the verses had been all sung and the
great table had been reached, the boar's head
was placed upon it, and the guests gathered
around to get a sprig of the ivy and twigs of the
holly to save as memorials, and the formal ceremony was ended. It only occupied ten or fifteen
minutes, but for hundreds of years every Christmas night has seen this same strange custom in
these ancient halls. Generations of college men
have come and gone, but still the boar's head
appears regularly every Christmas night and is
announced with the same trumpet flourish, is
ushered in with the same solemn procession and
is celebrated with the same carol to the same
tune.

there dwells in a certain city of India,
N the last
remnant of the oldest sect of the
"W,

oldest religion of Persia, which is older even
than the oldest religion of India, which is older
than Adam and Eve and the Garden of Eden,
but not Sc) old as the serpcnt. The high-priest
of this venerable religious body—the name of
which we will not mention for political reasons—
was to be hung publically in an open square of
the city, within two hours time, for burning
alive a young woman upon the sacerdotal altars
at which he officiated. His last was the highpriest's third offense. Thrice he had been caught
red handed; twice warned; once unofficially,
once officially. The mills of the Government of
India grind slowly, but they grind exceeding
small. So, upon the third known human sacrifice,the high-priest was to be hung in view of his
followers who, although confident in the advent
of a miracle at the eleventh hour, which would
free their leader and confound the unbelieving,
did not neglect the present opportunity of
swearing vengeance viciously and incessantly
upon His Excellency, the Viceroy of India, who
had refused to grant a pardon; upon that part

of the"Ould Regiment" which was"condhucting the carimonies," as Mulvaney said; and
lastly, but not leastly, upon one, Strickland, of
the police, who had put the local authorities
upon the track of the high-priest's religious
tendeancies, after—but that's another story.
The eleventh hour was approaching; the
the priest's followers redoubled their imprecations, the"Ould Regiment" drew together with
a click like the click of a rifle hammer drawn
back, and representatives of the other one—and
—seventy "jarring sects" hung upon the outskirts of the priest's clustered followers, ridiculing the latter with gusto, and hugely enjoying the excitement bred by a keen anticipation
of coming riots.
Around the base of the scaffold, the English
regiment, composed of Irishmen, was formed
into a hollow square hooped by a ridge of
bayonetts. Upon the scaffold English justice
was being done in a foreign land, according to
English standards.
The eleventh hour had come and gone, and
the twelfth. The priest was hung without
intervening miracle; his followers had departed
with one final long drawn wail, which ascended
key after key, hung taut for a second,and broke
into a shower of curses; the other one-andseventy "jarring sects" had cast their last jibe;
and Mulvaney, Ortheries, and Learoyd had
disbanded, to be reformed a moment later
around a can which may or may not have contained beer, but which smelt suspiciously. The
can had not completed one round, when Strickland, of the police and other departments not
officially labelled, broke in upon the three and
addressed them abruptly:
"Boys, have you anything to do to-night?"
But he prefaced his remarks by ostentatiously
counting and recounting three five-pound notes.
"Not a thing nor a soul left to do," answered
Mulvaney with a restropective sigh, "is there,
Ortheries ?"
"Hall hare done," replied the little man.
"Then," said Strickland, "I want you tonight."
"We a-are already predispoged in yo
- urfavor,"
said Mulvaney, eyeing the notes.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
It was Strickland who,disguised as one of the
high priest's followers, had discovered him conducting his third human sacrifice, but the work
was largely accomplished through the note of
another man whose name—which, for the purposes of this tale, is Story, John Savage Story—
had been stricken from the unofficial lists of the
police, because of ignorance of his whereabouts
for a year. The department was accustomed
to missing its officers for long periods at a time,
but John Savage Story had disappeared so completely and for so long a time, that the department had given up hope of recovering one of
its most valuable servants. Now Strickland
remembered the shouts of the priest's followers,
and he remembered wondering how his connection with the case had leaked through the
department. He afterwards found out in the
most peculiar manner, but that's another story.
Also, upon the morning of the execution, a
note had been dropped upon Strickland's office
floor by Genina, a cleaner of offices; to whom it
had been given by her lover, Goram See, a government clerk; to whom it had been given by
Moti-Guj, peddlar, from Delhi way; to whom it
had been given by a Thibetian horse-dealer; to
whom it had been given by the Pent-Up Beauty
who is not in the least pent up. Further than
this, Strickland could not go, even after a week's
labor. And the note read thusly:
"0 thou of many eyes, come to the tree near the
well of Bunder Lail, to the left of Mahomet's
Mole-hill, this night, a week, at midnight; if
thou woulcist learn something of great import
to the State."
And Strickland distroyed the note, thinking
meanwhile about his friend Storey, about his
disappearance, and the date thereof, which followed, as it happened closely upon his second
interference in the workings of an old and venerable religion. And as Strickland thought, his
face was not good to look upon.

stood in the shadow of Lal's Bezar and consulted vehemently, with many gesticulations.
And there came to them one dressed even as
they were who made signs upon his fingers, and
said:

"Brothers, is all well ?" And to this they
answered, "Aye" in chorus. Then the last
comer continued:
"Go ye armed ?" To which Abul Hamid replaied
"No,.brother, there are four of us, sufficient,
surely, to carry off a pig of a white man."
Whereupon the newcomer left them, and went
to a room, and came out Strickland. And the
man Strickland walked for an hour far past the
the suburbs of the city—followed at the distance
of five hundred paces by three of Her Majesty's
soldiers, apparently drunk—until he came to the
edge of a barren moonlit space, in the centre of
which stood a tree of heavy foliage; flanked on
the left by a well and on the right by a cluster of
foot hills, rising to the stumpy peak known as
"Mahomet's Mole-hill." Arrived at the edge
of this open space, Strickland slakened his pace
to a leisurely walk, whereupon the three who
followed him suddenly sobered and swung into
a quick dog trot, skirting behind the foothills.
For several minutes Strickland continued his
leisurely pace, then he stopped and consulted his
watch for a long while, to all appearances lost
in thought. Perhaps he was thinking of the fine
mark he made in the moonlight. Then there
came from the direction of Mahomet's Molehill the cry of the English skylark which does
not breed in India. Whereupon Strickland gave
a final decisive glance at his watch and quickened his pace.
The hour of midnight pealed over the city as
Strickland stood within the shadow of the tree,
where also another man stood—a native—who
engaged him in conversation, the details of
which Strickland says he does not remember for
Ile was listening to the branches over-head.
And presently, a man fell upon him from the
tree, and another dropped to the earth, and the
three bound, blindfolded, and gagged him and
marched him off across the barren place into a
woods. From thence, they all proceeded ten
miles across country, and as he stumbled along,
the sound of the sea grew louder in his ears.
When the party halted,the bandage was taken
from Strickland's eyes, and he saw that he

THE NEWS-LETTER.
SIR GEOFFRY'S CHRISTMAS.
Pr WAS Christmas day,
.11. And the bells did play
A jingling tune; and the crowd did sway
Helter-skelter through the gate—
Where old Sir Geoffry stood in state—
The tenants poured,
With one accord;
While old Sir Geoffry hemmed, and hawed,
As he stood, his oaken staff in hand,
While with a searching eye he scanned
Faces fair, and freckled, and tanned.
At last be spoke in a husky tone:—
"My people," said he,"I grieve to owe
That I'm not so rich as I was last year;
And so—you see—I greatly fear
That I cannot extend you the usual cheer;
And I do sincerely regret," said he,
"That there's only room at my board for me,
Besides my lady, and children three."
He paused: the crowd fell back a pace:
It really was a remarkable case,
That old Sir Geoffry should have the face
To say at his board they had no place,
For a good-natured curse
And a well-filled purse
Had never been wanting before they'd disperse.
Loud murmurs arose, and e'en some chaff,
At old "Sir Jeff" and his oaken staff;
On every side,
Both far and wide,
Surly looks met him, and people eyed
Him with disfavor; and one cried :—
"He pressed us sore
When our crops were poor
And we hadn't a groat in our scanty store;
But never before
In days of yore
Did he send us empty away from his door.
For years I laid by every cent,
On a decent burial to be spent;
And hark'ee, friends! Sir Geoffry went.
And took it all, for his blasted rent!"
Now on the outskirts of the crowd
Some vagrant ruffians laughed aloud;
To lose they had little, to gain they had less,
And they gave full rein to lawlessness.
"Aye, he has no room for us," one said,
" For he must have butter, while we have no bread.
'Tis such as he, give the king a bad name—
They do the ill, he bears the blame."
A stone went whizzing thro' the air.
The people jeered—some folk declare,
While the simple rustic bumpkins there,

Could only listen, and gape, and stare.
'Till then, Sir Geoffry stood amazed—
At first he thought his tenants crazed—
Bewildered, stricken dumb, and dazed,
He mutely stood, and gazed, and gazed;
When his astonishment was spent,
His rightious anger found its vent
"Fools! he cried,'twas my intent
In place of dobes to remit your rent.
But now—you go, without one cent!
Go! ye ingrates, one and all,
Get ye hence from my hearth and hall;
Others there be to whom I choose
To show the grace, which you abuse!"
Thunderstruck, stuperfied, quelled, and cowed,
Out through the archway poured the crowd;
And the bells did play a jingling tune
On that fair, wintery afternoon..
They went their ways as neath a spell;
The lesson was sharp, but they learned it well;
And to this day the peasants tell
That which on Chrstmas day befell.
—D. G. T.

TO THE MEN WHO HOLD THE LINE.
BEING A FOOTBALL TOAST.

Oh, the full-back bows to the cheering crowd,
And the halves, and the quarter, too,
And the praise ascends to the plucky ends
Who fight for the red or blue;
To none so great do I dedicate
This poor little verse of mine—
But here's to those in the fighting rows,
To the men who hold the line.
You watch the game and you'll all exclaim:
"Just look at that fellow run!"
And you'll shout and roar when the struggle's o'er,
That the game was only won
By the full-back's pluck in that splendid buck,
That carried him to the goal;
But you don't see fit to think a bit
Of the man who made the hole.
Yes, the full-back has his meed of thanks,
And the quarter 'did it all,"
And the halves are praised, and a voice is raised
For the ends who took the ball;
Now take your cup and fill it up
To the brim with the dancing wine;
A toast to those in the fighting rows,
To the men who hold the line!
—W. F. BARRON,'04,in the Georgetown CollegeJournal.

to pass upon the twelfth month

seventh day of the month, when the
OW

Freshites had gathered together in a great multitude, there arose one out of their midst and
spake unto them, saying—Harken ye unto my
words. Cast thine eyes about and behold these
thine enemies, even the men of the Juniorites,
how they go about to destroy. All day long do
they mock us, saying, Tish, Tish, behold what
babes and sucklings are these Freshites. Arise,
I say unto you, arise and let us sweep the
Juniorites from the face of the earth, nor suffer
them longer to delight in putting us to scorn.
Then the multitude of Freshites cried out with
one accord saying: So be it. On the morrow
will we rise early and smite them and cause
them to fall.
Now when these sayings came unto the ears
of the Juniorites they took counsel together
saying—What manner of speech is this? Do we
not possess the land as our heritage, and are
not the Freshites bound to serve us? Their
pride shooteth forth even as the green-bay tree
and causeth them to imagine vain things. It is
needful that we purge this wickedness from
their hearts.
And on the morrow the warriors of the
Freshites rose early and girded up their loins
and put upon them the armor of war and
strode from their tents, and the Juniorites did
likewise. And when they had assembled in a
great multitude upon the plain, the mighty men
of valor of the two tribes rushed heavily against
each other. Now for a great space of time the
strife waged even, but at the going down of
the sun the Juniorites prevailed. And it came
to pass when the Freshites beheld their mighty
men of battle put to confusion, they murmured
and said: Now let all the tribe come forth and
let us strive with our enemies. So at the sound
of the harp, and the timbrel, and the lute, and
the dulcimer, and the tabret the two tribes
rushed upon each other, and fell upon each
other's necks and strove after the rod of power,
and all the elders of the people fastened their
eyes upon them.

But again were the Freshites overcome by the
Juniorites, and utterly cast down. Then spake
the leader of the Freshites, saying: See the
thing that has come to pass, now the Juniorites
triumph over us. What are we to do? Then
answered the leader of the Juniorites, saying—
Behold what a shallow thing is the vanity of
man. Ye men of Fresh hearken unto our decrees
and it is well with thee, but see that ye be not
again lured from the path of righteousness to
hearken unto the counsel of vain speakers.
Nevertheless return ye to your tents and mercy
will be shown you. Then the Freshites making
lamentation gathered together the remnant of
their people and departed, every man to his
W. B. H.

LACROSSE CONVENTION.
Saturday, December 1, the annual conONvention
of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association was held in Philadelphia, with delegates
representing Johns Hopkins,Lehigh and Stevens.
After the regular routine business had been concluded, Mr. Abercrombie of the Hopkins delegation announced that it was the desire of the
University to withdraw from the Association.
A motion to this effect was made, but it was
laid on the table and the convention adjourned
to meet one week later, December 8, at South
Bethlehem, Pa.
At this meeting the question of the resignation
of the Hopkins team was considered. Our delegation enstead on its acceptance, stating that
under no conditions would the wearers of the
Black and Blue meet the Stevens team. After a
short discussion, it was decided to accept the
resignation, thus leaving only Lehigh and
Stevens in the old Intercollegiate Association.
Mr. Abercrombie states that at present there
is a movement on foot for the formation of a
new league, but will say nothing at all regarding the details of this project.
e‘,
Our delegates were Mr. Ronald). Abercrombie, captain of last year's team, and Manager
Harry S. Byrne. Captain Tyler was also present during the Convention.

EXULTEMUS!
wheel of time was turning fast
THE
When through the city's precincts passed,
A band of Juniors, brave and free,
Singing in voices rich, that "We,
Excel, Sir!"
A band of Freshmen shy and meek,
Who only in a whisper speak,
Slouch through the town in sullen gloom,
And in their hearts forecast their doom.
A sell, Sir!
Above the first in letters bold
Embroidered with a skein of gold,
Upon a field of blue and white
Proclaiming through the shining light,
"Excel, Sir!"
Upon a cloth of motley green
To all the world their shame is seen,
Not long doth it their misery crown,—
A Junior true hath torn it down,
A sell, Sir!
Through the winter's biting air
Is heard the Junior's cry ring clear,
As with their voices strong and bold,
To all the world their fame is told.
"Excel, sir."
The game is o'er; the game is ours,
And like the fall ofsummer showers,
The tears of Freshmen trickle down.
They whisper with a sullen frown,—
"A sell, Sir."
Fair maidens from the stand, in glee
With cheering voice do watch, as we
Line up in'strong and proud array,
To crown the glory of the day.
Excel, Sir!
From their fair hands the blue and white
Shines forth to us a guiding light.
No green is seen—oh pity sad!
To brighten up the verdant lad:
A sell, Sir!
The rush is o'er— poor nineteen three!
No need to count,— we know that we
With valiant swing have won the day,
For every thing has come our way.
"Excelsior."
—F. L. G.,'02.

FRESHMAN EXAMS.
AFTER TAKING.

one backward glance he leaves
WITHOUT
The awful room, with troubled mien,
For almost firmly he believes
The "board" hath squashed his fondest dream.
These hated schools of preparation,
That seem to haunt his mind forever;
The thought of which, spite creation,
Makes all his limbs with horror shiver—
Shiver as though had fallen smack,
A dash of water on his back—
As though his landlord, worthy gent,
Had failed to soak him for the rent.
And then off to his room he goes,
And sits before his blazing grate,
To muse a bit and toast his toes, •
And nerve himself to bear his fate,
And very flurried doth he look,
For hope hath nigh his mind forsook.
He jumps up with an awful shrug,
And kicks the cat clean off the rug;
Then paces up and down the floor,
And madly goes and slams the door;
Then takes a broom and pokes the fire,
And curses to his heart's desire;
His temples throb, he looks forlorn,
And wishes he had ne'er been born.
And once again he sits him down
Upon his tempting easy chair;
He looks about him with a frown,
And runs his fingers through his hair;
In deep remorse he calls the cat,
And gives her back her cozy place;
Then takes a book up off the mat,
But shortly flings it into space.
He mops his brow, and lights his lamp,
And tries to think, but finds he can't;
He tumbles on his couch and wonders—
"Passed or flunked?" until he slumbers.
W. H.

They were playing,they said, at a practice game
That they had oft played before,
And curious friends stood by and smiled
And wondered who would score.
But Cupid, as umpire, called the game
With a clear and cloudless sky,
And the minister smiled as he hung out the score
For the game had come out a "tie." —Ex.

A comparison of the summary of students at
Princeton and Hopkins reveals spme interesting
facts. Last year 1194 students, including 141
grads., 686 academic undergrads., 363 scientific
undergrads., were registered in the Princeton
Catalogue; and at Hopkins this year we have
160 graduate students excluding 211 candidates
for the degree of M. D., and the large number of
178 undergraduates, besides a few attending
special courses. It is not generally known that
Hopkins, in addition to establishing the high
standard for the Ph.D. degree, was the first
American University to introduce the system of
fellowships, an example soon followed by other
large colleges.

Half the undergraduates on the three Clubs

The presence of so many new men is felt to be a

Manager Bird is arranging for a series of concerts during the Christmas vacation. These

is probable that 1901 will find the Hopkins
Musical Clubs in a better condition than ever
before; but although this end is now in sight,
there it much to do before it can be reached.

December 20, 1900.

THE PROCESSION OF THE BOER'S
HEAD AT OXFORD.
BY AN OXFORD POST-GRADUATE.

WASHINGTON Irving describes in'his stories
of old Christmas at Bracebridge Hall how
the custom of bringing in the boar's head was
observed by the household of the Squire, that
delightful conservator of old English manners
and ceremonies. "I like the old custom," said
the Squire "not merely because it is stately and
pleasing in itself, but because it was observed at
the college at Oxford at which I was educated.
When Ihear the old song chanted, it brings to
mind the time when I wasyoung and gamesorne,—and the noble old college-hall,—and my
fellow-students loitering about in their black
gowns; many ofwhom, poor lads, are now in
their graves!"
And Irving observes, in a foot-note, that the
old custom is still kept up at the hall of Queen's
College, Oxford.
What Irving wrote fifty years ago still holds
good. On a recent Christmas Day I was present
in the hall of Queen's College, and witnessed the
quaint ceremony, heard the old chant that
Squire Bracebridge had heard in his young days
and never forgotten, and saw the students loitering around in black gowns in the noble old
college hall.
The hall is a fine lofty room, one of Sir Christopher Wren's designs, and is adorned with
many antique oil-paintings of kings,queens, and
benefactors. John Wycliffe, the early English
reformer, was a member of this college and a
great host of eminent men have been on its rolls,
—princes, poets, antiquarians and divines,—
among the princes, Edward the Black Prince,
and Henry V.
Two distinctive customs belong to Queen's
College and it clings to them almost religiously,
for these differentiate it from the twenty or more
other colleges at Oxford. One is this procession
of the boar's head at Christmas time. The
other is the gift of the needle and thread on

No. 5.

New Year's Day. At this latter ceremony, the
bursar presents each member or guest with a
needle and thread, repeating the words: "Take
this and be thrifty!" So has it been said every
year for many centuries.
The custom of the ushering-in of the boar's
head with the singing of a carol is said to commemorate the deliverance from death of a student of the college, who, while walking in the
country near Oxford studying his Aristotle, was
attacked by a wild boar from Shotover Forest.
He had no weapons. But Aristotle is a good
weapon when one knows how to use it. So he
thrust his Aristotle down the throat of the savage brute, and thus vaquished him. The next
day was Christmas, and they ate the boar on
that day, and ever since the same custom has
been observed.
This is how the custom is annually observed.
At half-past six the trumpet sounds forth some
hearty blasts. This is the signal that the procession is about to start from the kitchen and
the invited guests in the dining hall (and I
among them,)—wait in eager expectation for the
first appearance. First the provost of the college appeared, Dr. Magrath, who made a brief
speech in Latin. The provost is a learned man
and is not only provost of Queen's but vicechancellor of the University. He wore his official
gown. He was a handsome,dignified gentleman
with gray hair and beard.
After the speech the great oaken doors were
flung wide open, and the sounds of the carol began to be heard. A few minutes later the great
platter with the boar's head appeared. It was
carried on the shoulders of several college servitors. The boar's head was bravely and regally
arrayed. It lay on a bed of ivy and holly. It
was crowned with a great imitation golden
crown studded with imitation rubies. A cluster
of tiny college flags floated from each ear. And
under its saucy snout, between the two great
white tusks was a golden lemon.
As the procession reached the hall, it halted
and a collegian sang the first verse of the quaint

2

THE. NEWS-LETTER.

carol solo. Then the chorus was taken up by
the choir of men and boys—all gowned,—and the
procession moved again until the chorus ended,
then halted again while another verse was sung,
and so on to the end.
When the verses had been all sung and the
great table had been reached, the boar's head
was placed upon it, and the guests gathered
around to get a sprig of the ivy and twigs of the
holly to save as memorials, and the formal ceremony was ended. It only occupied ten or fifteen
minutes, but for hundreds of years every Christmas night has seen this same strange custom in
these ancient halls. Generations of college men
have come and gone, but still the boar's head
appears regularly every Christmas night and is
announced with the same trumpet flourish, is
ushered in with the same solemn procession and
is celebrated with the same carol to the same
tune.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
It was Strickland who,disguised as one of the
high priest's followers, had discovered him conducting his third human sacrifice, but the work
was largely accomplished through the note of
another man whose name—which, for the purposes of this tale, is Story, John Savage Story—
had been stricken from the unofficial lists of the
police, because of ignorance of his whereabouts
for a year. The department was accustomed
to missing its officers for long periods at a time,
but John Savage Story had disappeared so completely and for so long a time, that the department had given up hope of recovering one of
its most valuable servants. Now Strickland
remembered the shouts of the priest's followers,
and he remembered wondering how his connection with the case had leaked through the
department. He afterwards found out in the
most peculiar manner, but that's another story.
Also, upon the morning of the execution, a
note had been dropped upon Strickland's office
floor by Genina, a cleaner of offices; to whom it
had been given by her lover, Goram See, a government clerk; to whom it had been given by
Moti-Guj, peddlar, from Delhi way; to whom it
had been given by a Thibetian horse-dealer; to
whom it had been given by the Pent-Up Beauty
who is not in the least pent up. Further than
this, Strickland could not go, even after a week's
labor. And the note read thusly:
"0 thou of many eyes, come to the tree near the
well of Bunder Lail, to the left of Mahomet's
Mole-hill, this night, a week, at midnight; if
thou woulcist learn something of great import
to the State."
And Strickland distroyed the note, thinking
meanwhile about his friend Storey, about his
disappearance, and the date thereof, which followed, as it happened closely upon his second
interference in the workings of an old and venerable religion. And as Strickland thought, his
face was not good to look upon.

And there came to them one dressed even as

"Go ye armed ?" To which Abul Hamid replaied

Whereupon the newcomer left them, and went

man Strickland walked for an hour far past the
the suburbs of the city—followed at the distance
of five hundred paces by three of Her Majesty's
soldiers, apparently drunk—until he came to the
edge of a barren moonlit space, in the centre of
which stood a tree of heavy foliage; flanked on
the left by a well and on the right by a cluster of
foot hills, rising to the stumpy peak known as
"Mahomet's Mole-hill." Arrived at the edge
of this open space, Strickland slakened his pace
to a leisurely walk, whereupon the three who
followed him suddenly sobered and swung into
a quick dog trot, skirting behind the foothills.
For several minutes Strickland continued his
leisurely pace, then he stopped and consulted his
watch for a long while, to all appearances lost
in thought. Perhaps he was thinking of the fine
mark he made in the moonlight. Then there
came from the direction of Mahomet's Molehill the cry of the English skylark which does
not breed in India. Whereupon Strickland gave
a final decisive glance at his watch and quickened his pace.
The hour of midnight pealed over the city as
Strickland stood within the shadow of the tree,
where also another man stood—a native—who
engaged him in conversation, the details of
which Strickland says he does not remember for
Ile was listening to the branches over-head.
And presently, a man fell upon him from the
tree, and another dropped to the earth, and the
three bound, blindfolded, and gagged him and
marched him off across the barren place into a
woods. From thence, they all proceeded ten
miles across country, and as he stumbled along,
the sound of the sea grew louder in his ears.

While old Sir Geoffry hemmed, and hawed,
As he stood, his oaken staff in hand,
While with a searching eye he scanned
Faces fair, and freckled, and tanned.
At last be spoke in a husky tone:—
"My people," said he,"I grieve to owe
That I'm not so rich as I was last year;
And so—you see—I greatly fear
That I cannot extend you the usual cheer;
And I do sincerely regret," said he,
"That there's only room at my board for me,
Besides my lady, and children three."
He paused: the crowd fell back a pace:
It really was a remarkable case,
That old Sir Geoffry should have the face
To say at his board they had no place,
For a good-natured curse
And a well-filled purse
Had never been wanting before they'd disperse.
Loud murmurs arose, and e'en some chaff,
At old "Sir Jeff" and his oaken staff;
On every side,
Both far and wide,
Surly looks met him, and people eyed
Him with disfavor; and one cried :—
"He pressed us sore
When our crops were poor
And we hadn't a groat in our scanty store;
But never before
In days of yore
Did he send us empty away from his door.
For years I laid by every cent,
On a decent burial to be spent;
And hark'ee, friends! Sir Geoffry went.
And took it all, for his blasted rent!"
Now on the outskirts of the crowd
Some vagrant ruffians laughed aloud;
To lose they had little, to gain they had less,
And they gave full rein to lawlessness.
"Aye, he has no room for us," one said,
" For he must have butter, while we have no bread.
'Tis such as he, give the king a bad name—
They do the ill, he bears the blame."
A stone went whizzing thro' the air.
The people jeered—some folk declare,
While the simple rustic bumpkins there,

Could only listen, and gape, and stare.
'Till then, Sir Geoffry stood amazed—
At first he thought his tenants crazed—
Bewildered, stricken dumb, and dazed,
He mutely stood, and gazed, and gazed;
When his astonishment was spent,
His rightious anger found its vent
"Fools! he cried,'twas my intent
In place of dobes to remit your rent.
But now—you go, without one cent!
Go! ye ingrates, one and all,
Get ye hence from my hearth and hall;
Others there be to whom I choose
To show the grace, which you abuse!"
Thunderstruck, stuperfied, quelled, and cowed,
Out through the archway poured the crowd;
And the bells did play a jingling tune
On that fair, wintery afternoon..
They went their ways as neath a spell;
The lesson was sharp, but they learned it well;
And to this day the peasants tell
That which on Chrstmas day befell.
—D. G. T.

TO THE MEN WHO HOLD THE LINE.
BEING A FOOTBALL TOAST.

Oh, the full-back bows to the cheering crowd,
And the halves, and the quarter, too,
And the praise ascends to the plucky ends
Who fight for the red or blue;
To none so great do I dedicate
This poor little verse of mine—
But here's to those in the fighting rows,
To the men who hold the line.
You watch the game and you'll all exclaim:
"Just look at that fellow run!"
And you'll shout and roar when the struggle's o'er,
That the game was only won
By the full-back's pluck in that splendid buck,
That carried him to the goal;
But you don't see fit to think a bit
Of the man who made the hole.
Yes, the full-back has his meed of thanks,
And the quarter 'did it all,"
And the halves are praised, and a voice is raised
For the ends who took the ball;
Now take your cup and fill it up
To the brim with the dancing wine;
A toast to those in the fighting rows,
To the men who hold the line!
—W. F. BARRON,'04,in the Georgetown CollegeJournal.

HERE ENDETH THE SECOND LESSON.
(III CHRONICLES, CHAPTER 14, v. 37-51).

to pass upon the twelfth month

seventh day of the month, when the
OW

Freshites had gathered together in a great multitude, there arose one out of their midst and
spake unto them, saying—Harken ye unto my
words. Cast thine eyes about and behold these
thine enemies, even the men of the Juniorites,
how they go about to destroy. All day long do
they mock us, saying, Tish, Tish, behold what
babes and sucklings are these Freshites. Arise,
I say unto you, arise and let us sweep the
Juniorites from the face of the earth, nor suffer
them longer to delight in putting us to scorn.
Then the multitude of Freshites cried out with
one accord saying: So be it. On the morrow
will we rise early and smite them and cause
them to fall.
Now when these sayings came unto the ears
of the Juniorites they took counsel together
saying—What manner of speech is this? Do we
not possess the land as our heritage, and are
not the Freshites bound to serve us? Their
pride shooteth forth even as the green-bay tree
and causeth them to imagine vain things. It is
needful that we purge this wickedness from
their hearts.
And on the morrow the warriors of the
Freshites rose early and girded up their loins
and put upon them the armor of war and
strode from their tents, and the Juniorites did
likewise. And when they had assembled in a
great multitude upon the plain, the mighty men
of valor of the two tribes rushed heavily against
each other. Now for a great space of time the
strife waged even, but at the going down of
the sun the Juniorites prevailed. And it came
to pass when the Freshites beheld their mighty
men of battle put to confusion, they murmured
and said: Now let all the tribe come forth and
let us strive with our enemies. So at the sound
of the harp, and the timbrel, and the lute, and
the dulcimer, and the tabret the two tribes
rushed upon each other, and fell upon each
other's necks and strove after the rod of power,
and all the elders of the people fastened their
eyes upon them.

But again were the Freshites overcome by the
Juniorites, and utterly cast down. Then spake
the leader of the Freshites, saying: See the
thing that has come to pass, now the Juniorites
triumph over us. What are we to do? Then
answered the leader of the Juniorites, saying—
Behold what a shallow thing is the vanity of
man. Ye men of Fresh hearken unto our decrees
and it is well with thee, but see that ye be not
again lured from the path of righteousness to
hearken unto the counsel of vain speakers.
Nevertheless return ye to your tents and mercy
will be shown you. Then the Freshites making
lamentation gathered together the remnant of
their people and departed, every man to his
W. B. H.

LACROSSE CONVENTION.
Saturday, December 1, the annual conONvention
of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association was held in Philadelphia, with delegates
representing Johns Hopkins,Lehigh and Stevens.
After the regular routine business had been concluded, Mr. Abercrombie of the Hopkins delegation announced that it was the desire of the
University to withdraw from the Association.
A motion to this effect was made, but it was
laid on the table and the convention adjourned
to meet one week later, December 8, at South
Bethlehem, Pa.
At this meeting the question of the resignation
of the Hopkins team was considered. Our delegation enstead on its acceptance, stating that
under no conditions would the wearers of the
Black and Blue meet the Stevens team. After a
short discussion, it was decided to accept the
resignation, thus leaving only Lehigh and
Stevens in the old Intercollegiate Association.
Mr. Abercrombie states that at present there
is a movement on foot for the formation of a
new league, but will say nothing at all regarding the details of this project.
e‘,
Our delegates were Mr. Ronald). Abercrombie, captain of last year's team, and Manager
Harry S. Byrne. Captain Tyler was also present during the Convention.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
EXULTEMUS!
wheel of time was turning fast
THE
When through the city's precincts passed,
A band of Juniors, brave and free,
Singing in voices rich, that "We,
Excel, Sir!"
A band of Freshmen shy and meek,
Who only in a whisper speak,
Slouch through the town in sullen gloom,
And in their hearts forecast their doom.
A sell, Sir!
Above the first in letters bold
Embroidered with a skein of gold,
Upon a field of blue and white
Proclaiming through the shining light,
"Excel, Sir!"
Upon a cloth of motley green
To all the world their shame is seen,
Not long doth it their misery crown,—
A Junior true hath torn it down,
A sell, Sir!
Through the winter's biting air
Is heard the Junior's cry ring clear,
As with their voices strong and bold,
To all the world their fame is told.
"Excel, sir."
The game is o'er; the game is ours,
And like the fall ofsummer showers,
The tears of Freshmen trickle down.
They whisper with a sullen frown,—
"A sell, Sir."
Fair maidens from the stand, in glee
With cheering voice do watch, as we
Line up in'strong and proud array,
To crown the glory of the day.
Excel, Sir!
From their fair hands the blue and white
Shines forth to us a guiding light.
No green is seen—oh pity sad!
To brighten up the verdant lad:
A sell, Sir!
The rush is o'er— poor nineteen three!
No need to count,— we know that we
With valiant swing have won the day,
For every thing has come our way.
"Excelsior."
—F. L. G.,'02.

FRESHMAN EXAMS.
AFTER TAKING.

one backward glance he leaves
WITHOUT
The awful room, with troubled mien,
For almost firmly he believes
The "board" hath squashed his fondest dream.
These hated schools of preparation,
That seem to haunt his mind forever;
The thought of which, spite creation,
Makes all his limbs with horror shiver—
Shiver as though had fallen smack,
A dash of water on his back—
As though his landlord, worthy gent,
Had failed to soak him for the rent.
And then off to his room he goes,
And sits before his blazing grate,
To muse a bit and toast his toes, •
And nerve himself to bear his fate,
And very flurried doth he look,
For hope hath nigh his mind forsook.
He jumps up with an awful shrug,
And kicks the cat clean off the rug;
Then paces up and down the floor,
And madly goes and slams the door;
Then takes a broom and pokes the fire,
And curses to his heart's desire;
His temples throb, he looks forlorn,
And wishes he had ne'er been born.
And once again he sits him down
Upon his tempting easy chair;
He looks about him with a frown,
And runs his fingers through his hair;
In deep remorse he calls the cat,
And gives her back her cozy place;
Then takes a book up off the mat,
But shortly flings it into space.
He mops his brow, and lights his lamp,
And tries to think, but finds he can't;
He tumbles on his couch and wonders—
"Passed or flunked?" until he slumbers.
W. H.

A comparison of the summary of students at
Princeton and Hopkins reveals spme interesting
facts. Last year 1194 students, including 141
grads., 686 academic undergrads., 363 scientific
undergrads., were registered in the Princeton
Catalogue; and at Hopkins this year we have
160 graduate students excluding 211 candidates
for the degree of M. D., and the large number of
178 undergraduates, besides a few attending
special courses. It is not generally known that
Hopkins, in addition to establishing the high
standard for the Ph.D. degree, was the first
American University to introduce the system of
fellowships, an example soon followed by other
large colleges.
